tools: Two sets of Artisan's Tools of your choice

default: (a) Any two {@filter simple weapons|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=simple weapon} of your choice.
(a) A {@item light crossbow} and {@item bolts|phb|20 bolts} or (b) a {@item rapier|phb|rapier}.
One set of Artisan's Tools of your choice.
Leather armor and a Scholar's Pack.

tools: An Artisan's Tools of your choice

entries: The slender elf cleans his glasses with the corner of his cloak as the dust settles around him. He was the first living thing to set foot in the ancient temple in hundreds of years. His benefactor had paid him a great deal to find this place, and after months of pouring over forgotten tomes he had finally figured out it's long-lost location. Now, he had a choice to make, would he report back to his benefactor allowing them to strip the temple of it's valuables? Or, would he keep the location hidden, and preserve the priceless information found here himself? To a Savant, knowledge is more precious than gold coins.

The elderly warrior assessed the state of his men, they were exhausted and almost out of supplies. This was the tenth day of the siege, and the warrior knew that at this point no reinforcements were coming to relieve them. He was too old to be of use in battle, but if his men followed his orders to the letter, and without hesitation, they just might have a fighting chance. He stood up, and for what could be the last time, drew his sword.

A young dwarf bends over his unconscious comrade in the midst of battle, his hands shaking as he examined the unconscious soldier's wounds. The elders of his clan had spent a great deal of their fortune to send him to the best university gold could buy. All those hours spent in lectures, libraries, and observation; all for this moment. He thought back to what he had learned about field medicine from his professors and began to dress the soldier's wounds.

entries.name: Great Minds
entries: There are many intelligent people in the world, but few are true Savants. Born with with an innate desire to learn all they can, and the potential for a genius level intellect, they spend their lives studying anything that those around them are willing to teach them. Savants are often recognized at an early age, and in their hunger for knowledge, they are drawn to great libraries, universities, and other places of higher learning. They will do anything to access the troves of knowledge that lie hidden in the forgotten places of the world, for Savants, no price is too steep to pay for a new discovery.

Despite their aptitude for learning, most Savants seek to better themselves without having to rely on outside influences. Savants reject the patronage of gods and other powerful beings, and in turn they view wizardry as a shortcut to power for the weak willed. Relying on their intellect alone, they strive for perfection.

entries.name: Intense Focus
entries: Savants tend to hyper-focus on their chosen area of expertise. They obsess over it, learning all they can about the subject. Once they reach the climax of learning in that specialty, and there is nothing anyone else can teach them, they do not move on. Instead they will go to great lengths, risking life and limb, to advance their chosen field of study.

Often doing so at great cost to themselves, Savants will not stop researching, experimenting, and theorizing until they have made an indelible mark on their academic discipline. A Savant's ultimate goal in life is to discover some previously unknown truth about the universe.

entries.name: Creating a Savant
entries: When creating your Savant consider their upbringing and level of formal education. Where they the star pupil of the kingdom's university? Or did they come from nothing, fighting for any scrap of knowledge they could get their hands on? Were they naturally intelligent, but unable to use their abilities because of obligations to family?

Whatever their origins, consider why they became an adventurer rather than an academic. Did they learn all they could from the dusty tomes in the library, and now they seek to discover forgotten temples and the knowledge within? Have they advanced beyond study and look to the endless discoveries of a life of adventure?

entries.name: Quick Build
entries: You can make a Savant quickly by following these suggestions. First, put your highest ability score in Intelligence, followed by Dexterity. Second, choose the Sage background from the Player's Handbook.

entries.name: Academic Disciplines
entries: A Savant's Academic Discipline is the focus of their considerable intellect and not a decision they make lightly. The following Academic Disciplines are available to a Savant; Archaeologist, Naturalist, Philosopher, Physician, or Tactician. Your Academic Discipline grants you features at 3rd, 7th, 13th, and 17th levels.

entries.name: Archaeologist
entries: Specializing in the study of ancient places, forgotten cities, and uncharted lands, Archaeologists boldly walk into the dark and deadly places of the world that they may be illuminated by the light of knowledge. Often funded by powerful politicians, universities, wizards, and other seekers of esoteric knowledge, this way of life has the potential for great profit, if you manage to survive.

Archaeologists do their best to piece together the lost knowledge of past ages. They tend to feel a sad kinship with the lost civilizations that they study, and will go to great lengths not to destroy or offend their memory. For an Archaeologist, learning from the innovations, and mistakes, of the past is the best way to improve the present and blaze a trail towards a better future.

entries.name: Naturalist
entries: The Naturalist's classroom begins at the very edges of civilization. They study the environments, flora, and fauna that live beyond the influence of civilized peoples. Naturalists are experts at anticipating weather patterns, knowing the difference between an edible plant and a toxic one, and understanding the behaviors of wild animals. Highly sought after as guides for adventuring parties, Naturalists can safely navigate arid deserts, frigid mountain ranges, and treacherous jungles.

entries.name: Physician
entries: Mortals have studied the inner workings of living things. Clerics and priests of gods of life and healing, necromancers and despicable liches who seek to raise the dead, and lethal assassins and warriors who learn the most vulnerable points to strike. Unlike all of these, Physicians use their knowledge and mundane science to heal wounds, cure diseases, perform surgeries, and generally improve the quality of life for those that cannot afford the luxury of magical healing.
As a Physician, you bring you considerable intellect to bear to tend the wounds of any creatures that need your help.

entries.name: Philosopher
entries: Philosophy is the purest of the Academic Disciplines that Savants pursue. Philosophers spend their lives pondering the deep questions of existence - What is the purpose of life? Why did the gods create the multiverse? What is the nature of the material plane and the planes that surround it?

Through their study of mathematics, physics, natural sciences, and public speaking, they seek to perfect their knowledge of reality and their place in it. Philosophers make invaluable advisors and thinkers when they are on your side. They range from humble village elders to imperial advisors.

entries.name: Seeker
entries: In every society there are those that look to deceive, swindle, and take advantage of the trust of others. Thieves Guilds that run racketeering schemes, monsters that change their appearance to deceive the innocent, and those who abuse their legitimate authority to extort those who follow the law. Standing in their way is the archetypal Seeker, those who bend their considerable intellect to uncover the truth.

As a Seeker, you excel at rooting out secrets and unraveling mysteries. You rely on your sharp eye for detail, but also on your finely honed ability to read the words and deeds of other creatures to determine their true intent. You excel at defeating creatures that hide among and prey upon ordinary folk, and your mastery of lore and your sharp eye make you well equipped to expose and end hidden evils.

entries.name: Tactician
entries: Every successful king, conquerer, or rebellion has a master strategist that is responsible for their success on the battlefield. Tacticians constantly work to stay one step ahead of their enemies, and have a plan prepared for every eventuality. They focus on the big picture, and while they may not win every battle, they strive to win the war.

You have spent your time studying the art of war and long forgotten histories of conquest and glory. You know the strategies that lead to victory, and those that end in ruin. Alone you are no threat, but with powerful allies to command, you are a force to be reckoned with.

classFeature.name: Adroit Analysis
entries: Starting at 1st level, you can make use of your lightning fast cognitive skills even as you engage in battle. As a bonus action on your turn, you can make an ability check with any skill or tool you are proficient with.

You can also use this ability to analyze the movement patterns and fighting style of an enemy creature. As a bonus action, you choose a creature that you can see within 60 feet and designate it as the target of your analysis. Whenever you make an attack against the designated creature, using a weapon with which you are proficient that lacks the heavy property, you gain a bonus to the attack roll equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1).

The effects of your Adroit Analysis last for one minute, or until you fall unconscious. If you designate another creature as the target of your Adroit Analysis any effects immediately end for the previous target.

classFeature.name: Unarmored Defense
entries: Beginning at 1st level, your observant way of fighting allows you to predict enemy attacks and react to them with lightning fast accuracy. When you are not wearing any armor or using a shield your armor class is equal to 10 + your Dexterity modifier + your Intelligence modifier.

classFeature.name: Perfect Recall
entries: Your photographic memory allows you to remember even the most minute details. Starting at 2nd level, if you spend at least one minute observing and committing something to memory you can automatically recall any information about your observations at any point in the future.
Examples include books you've read, the appearance of an acquaintance, a dungeon map, or a path you've traveled.

classFeature.name: Unyielding Mind
entries: Beginning at 2nd level, your mind has been honed into both a potent observational weapon and a stalwart shield against mental assaults. As a reaction, when you make an Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma ability check or a saving throw, you can roll a d4 and add the number rolled to the ability check or saving throw. You use this feature after you roll, but before you determine whether you succeed or fail.
The size of the die you roll for this ability increases at 10th level (1d6), 15th level (1d8), and 20th level (1d10).

classFeature.name: Academic Discipline
entries: At 3rd level, you choose your Academic Discipline. Choose between Archaeologist, Naturalist, Philosopher, Physician, or Tactician, each of which is detailed at the end of this class description. Your Academic Discipline grants you features at 3rd, 7th, 13th, and 17th levels.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Accelerated Reflexes
entries: Beginning at 5th level, your ability to process the world around you moves notably faster. You can take on additional Reaction per round. Once you use both Reactions you cannot take another until the beginning of your next turn. A single effect can only trigger one Reaction.
Upon reaching 17th level you can take up to three Reactions per round of combat.

classFeature.name: Potent Observation
entries: Starting at 5th level you can instruct your allies to better exploit the weak points of your foes. When a creature that you can see hits the target of your Adroit Analysis with a weapon or spell attack you can use your reaction to increase the damage dealt. The attack deals an additional 1d10 of its damage type. If the attack deals more then one type of damage the creature making the attack determines the type of this bonus damage.

classFeature.name: Expert Student
entries: Upon reaching 6th level, your ability and desire to learn new things is unrivaled. At the end of a short or long rest you can choose to learn one additional language of your choice, or gain one tool, skill, or weapon proficiency of your choice, as long as there is an example for you to learn from (like a teacher or manual). You can only gain one bonus proficiency per short or long rest.

You can have a number of bonus proficiencies from this ability equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1). If you choose to learn another bonus proficiency when you are at your maximum you must choose another proficiency you gained from this ability to forget.

entries.name: Appetite for Knowledge!
entries: Savants are the archetypal learner, desperate for knowledge of all kinds. Make sure to use your Expert Student ability to emphasize this aspect of your Savant. Learn local languages, practice skills, and learn to use new and exciting weapons!

classFeature.name: Academic Discipline Feature
entries: At 7th level, you gain a feature granted by your Academic Discipline.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats. html}.

classFeature.name: Expert Educator
entries: Beginning at 9th level you can share your knowledge with others in a short amount of time. Choose one skill, tool, or weapon you are proficient with, or one language you know. At the end of a long rest, a number of creatures of your choice equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1) that can hear you gain that proficiency or learn the language. The benefits of this ability last until the end of your next long rest.
The proficiency or language you choose to teach with this ability can be one that you've acquired from Expert Student.

classFeature.name: Unyielding Mind Improvement
entries: Upon reaching 10th level, increase the size of the die for your Unyielding Mind ability (1d6).

classFeature.name: Reliable Talent
entries: You have mastered all known knowledge in your areas of study, and it is exceedingly rare that you encounter something unheard of. Beginning at 11th level, whenever you make an ability check that lets you add your proficiency bonus, you can treat a d20 roll of 9 or lower as a 10.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats. html}.

classFeature.name: Academic Discipline Feature
entries: At 13th level, you gain a feature granted by your Academic Discipline.

classFeature.name: Mental Fortitude
entries: Starting at 14th level you have learned to steel your mind against effects that remove your mental agency. If you fail a saving throw to resist being charmed, frightened, or stunned, you can choose to automatically succeed instead.
Once you use this ability you must complete a short or long rest before you can use it again.

classFeature.name: Unyielding Mind Improvement
entries: Upon reaching 15th level, increase the size of the die for your Unyielding Mind ability (1d8).

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats. html}.

classFeature.name: Academic Discipline Feature
entries: At 17th level, you gain a feature granted by your Academic Discipline.

classFeature.name: Accelerated Reflexes Improvement
entries: Upon reaching 17th level, you can take up to three Reactions per round of combat.

classFeature.name: Profound Insight
entries: Beginning at 18th level, your almost supernatural ability to process the world around you allows you to predict your enemy's attacks as they happen. When an enemy creature is designated by Adroit Analysis they have disadvantage on any attack roll they make against you, and you have advantage on any saving throw they force you to make.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats. html}.

classFeature.name: Unyielding Mind Improvement
entries: Upon reaching 20th level, increase the size of the die for your Unyielding Mind ability (1d10).

classFeature.name: Undisputed Genius
entries: Upon reaching 20th level, you realize the wondrous potential of your intellect. Both your Intelligence score, and maximum Intelligence score, increase by 4.

subclassFeature.name: Student of History
entries: Starting at 3rd level your study of bygone eras allows you unique insight into ancient and forgotten things. When you adopt this Academic Discipline you learn two exotic languages of your choice. In addition you gain proficiency and Expertise in the History and Investigation skills, which means your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make with these skills. If you are already proficient in History or Investigation you gain proficiency with another skill of your choice from the savant skill list.

Additionally, your familiarity with civilizations both modern and ancient, allows you to glean additional types of information through observation. When you designate a creature as the target of your Adroit Analysis you learn of either one language spoken by the creature or one special sense they may have.

subclassFeature.name: Daring Determination
entries: Ancient temples and forgotten dungeons are deadly to most, but your time in such places has honed your survival instincts. Starting at 3rd level you gain the following benefits:

items: It only takes 5 feet of your movement speed to stand up from the prone position.
As a reaction, you can apply your Unyielding Mind feature when you make a Dexterity ability check or when you are forced to make a Dexterity saving throw.

If you spend one minute examining an object, you can ascertain the monetary worth of the object, the civilization of origin of the object, and the approximate age of the object. If the item has any magical properties you discern them as if you had cast the {@spell identify|PhB} spell.

subclassFeature.name: Survivalist
entries: In your time exploring the depths of ancient places you have learned to better defend yourself from the dangers that lie within. Starting at 7th level, when the creature you have designated with your Adroit Analysis targets you with an opportunity attack they have disadvantage on the attack roll.

In addition, you have picked up a few underhanded techniques you can use to better protect yourself. When you hit a creature designated by your Adroit Analysis with a weapon attack you can force them to make a Dexterity saving throw in addition to the attack's normal damage. The DC is equal to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Intelligence modifier. On a failed save the target is blinded, deafened, or knocked prone (your choice). If you choose blinded or deafened the condition lasts until the start of your next turn.
You can use this ability a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Use Magical Device
entries: Starting at 13th level, your familiarity with eldritch artifacts allows you to operate them with ease. You ignore all alignment, class, race, and level requirements for the use of magic items.

subclassFeature.name: Master Archaeologist
entries: Upon reaching 17th level your frequent exposure to the magical effects present in ancient places has caused your body to develop an innate arcane ward. You are resistant to all damage from spells and other magical effects.

subclassFeature.name: Student of Nature
entries: Beginning at 3rd level your time studying the natural world has granted you a unique insight into the ways of the wild. When you adopt this Academic Discipline you gain proficiency and Expertise in Animal Handling and Nature, which means your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make with these skills. If you are already proficient in Animal Handling or Nature you gain proficiency with another skill of your choice from the savant skill list.

Additionally, your familiarity with creature types allows you to glean additional information through observation. When you designate a creature as the target of your Adroit Analysis you learn either its creature type, its highest or its lowest ability score.

subclassFeature.name: Conservationist
entries: Starting at 3rd level, your study of natural flora and fauna has given you insight into their weak points. Your weapon attacks that target a beast, monstrosity, or plant designated by your Adroit Analysis score a critical hit on a roll of 19 or 20.

Additionally, at the end of a long rest, you can attune yourself to the natural environment you are currently in (examples include, but are not limited to, arctic, coast, desert, forest, grassland, jungle, mountain, swamp, or underdark). While in that environment you have advantage on any Intelligence or Wisdom ability checks you make related to native animals, plants, ecosystem or weather.

subclassFeature.name: Outdoorsman
entries: Upon reaching 7th level, you can use your knowledge of the wilderness to better guide your allies. At the end of a long rest you can prepare friendly creatures for upcoming dangers. You and a number of friendly creatures equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1) gain one of the benefits listed below, which last until the end of your next long rest.
{@b Active Training}. Creatures ignore the effects difficult terrain imposed by natural environments and their base walking speed is increased by 10 feet.
{@b Concealment Training}. Creatures can move stealthily at a normal pace and can take the Hide action as a bonus action.
{@b Diver Training}. Creatures gain a swim speed equal to their move speed, and can hold their breath for a number of minutes equal to their Constitution score.

{@b Extreme Environment Training}. Creatures gain resistance to one of the following damage types (your choice); cold, fire, poison, or thunder damage, and have advantage on saving throws to resist the effects of extreme environments.
{@b Mountaineer Training}. Creatures gain a climb speed equal to their move speed and reduce any falling damage they take by an amount equal to your Savant level.

subclassFeature.name: Wild Insights
entries: You've come to understand the animals of the natural world in a way that few civilized peoples do. Starting at 13th level, as an action you can touch a beast or plant and attempt to charm it as if casting the dominate beast spell. The save DC is equal to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Intelligence modifier. This ability can effect plants as well as beasts.
You may use this feature a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of once). You regain all uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Master Naturalist
entries: You have become a leading authority on the natural world, and can maneuver with comfort in any natural environment you find yourself in. Starting at 17th level you automatically attune to your current environment for the purposes of Conservationist ability, and you gain the benefits of all Outdoorsman features while you are conscious.

subclassFeature.name: Student of Thought
entries: When you adopt this Academic Discipline at 3rd level you gain proficiency and Expertise in Arcana and Religion, which means your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make with these skills. If you are already proficient in Arcana or Religion you gain proficiency with another skill of your choice from the savant skill list.

Additionally, your time studying the nature of existence allows you to glean additional types of information through observation. When you designate a creature as the target of your Adroit Analysis you learn the either it's plane of origin, spellcasting ability (if it has one), or the level of the highest spell it can cast.

subclassFeature.name: Resounding Theorems
entries: Starting at 3rd level, your mastery over the spoken word allows you to shake the fabric of reality with your speech. As an action on your turn you can speak one of the theorems below aloud targeting a creature that can hear you within 60 feet. Creatures do not need to understand you to be effected.
Saving Throws. Some of your theorems require your target to make a saving throw to resist the theorem's effects. The saving throw DC is calculated as follows:

items: {@b Confounding Theorem}. You assault the mind of a foe with a potent word. The target must make an Intelligence saving throw. A target takes 1d10 psychic damage on a failed save, and half as much damage on a successful one. The damage of this theorem increases by 1d10 when you reach 5th level (2d10), 11th level (3d10), and 17th level (4d10).

{@b Disarming Theorem}. You calm a creature with soothing speech. The target must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is charmed by you until the start next turn or until your companions do anything harmful to it.

{@b Disorienting Theorem}. You weave words that distract a foe. The target must make an Intelligence saving throw. On a failed save, the target has disadvantage on all saving throws they make until the beginning of your next turn.

{@b Inspiring Theorem}. Your words bolster the resolve of an ally. The target can add your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1) to either all attack rolls, ability checks, or saving throws (your choice) until the beginning of your next turn.

{@b Sapping Theorem}. Your words of power weaken the place of a creature in reality. The target must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the target gains one level of exhaustion. The creature can make a Constitution saving throw at the end of each of its turns, removing one level of exhaustion on a success.

subclassFeature.name: Unwavering Belief
entries: Beginning at 7th level, your confidence in your purpose is unwavering. You gain proficiency in Charisma saving throws.

In addition, when a creature designated by your Adroit Analysis fails the saving throw for one of your theorems you can choose to deal psychic damage to the creature equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1) in addition to the affects of the theorem.

subclassFeature.name: Supreme Understanding
entries: Starting at 13th level, your mastery over the spoken word allows you to speak even more powerful theorems. You learn the following supreme theorems.

items: {@b Debilitating Theorem}. You twist your speech to sow discord in the minds of your enemies. The target must make an Intelligence saving throw. On a failed save, the target is stunned for one minute. The target can make an Intelligence saving throw each time it takes damage, ending the effect on itself on a success.

{@b Undermining Theorem}. You speak a word that shunts a creature from your plane of existence. The target must make a Charisma saving throw. On a failed save they are shunted to the astral plane for one minute. The target can make a Charisma saving throw at the end of each of its turns, returning to your plane of existence on a success.
Once you speak a supreme theorem you cannot speak another again until you complete a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Master Philosopher
entries: When you reach 17th level, your willpower is unwavering. You are always under the effects of the protection from evil and good spell while you are conscious.
In addition, you can speak two supreme theorems, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Student of Medicine
entries: When you adopt this Academic Discipline at 3rd level, Medicine becomes an Intelligence-based skill for you. You gain proficiency and Expertise in Medicine and with the Herbalism Kit, which means your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make with either of these proficiencies. If you are already proficient in Medicine or with the Herbalism Kit you gain proficiency with another skill or tool of your choice from the savant skill list.

In addition, your time studying anatomy allows you to glean additional information through observation. When you designate a creature as the target of your Adroit Analysis you learn the creature's current hit points.

subclassFeature.name: Combat Medic
entries: Starting at 3rd level when you dedicate your life to the study of medicine you gain the following abilities. As an action, you can use one of the following abilities detailed below:

items: {@b Adrenaline Boost}. A creature you touch can use its reaction to immediately repeat a saving throw to end one of the following conditions; blinded, charmed, deafened, frightened, or poisoned. They gain a bonus to their roll equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1).

{@b Crippling Strike}. You make a weapon attack against an enemy creature, targeting an anatomical weak point. On hit, instead of dealing damage, its movement speed is reduced by an amount of feet equal to 5 times your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 5 feet) until the start of your next turn.

{@b Dress Wounds}. You bandage a creature's wounds, allowing them to fight on. A creature you touch immediately gains temporary hit points equal to 1d6 + your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1), replacing any current temporary hit points they may have.

{@b Healing Surge}. Using medicinal techniques you stimulate natural healing in a creature. A creature you touch can use its reaction to expend one of their hit dice. It immediately regains hit points equal to their hit die roll + your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1). This ability has no effect unconscious or dead creatures.

{@b Stabilize}. You use your knowledge to stabilize an injured creature. You touch a living creature that has 0 hit points and the creature becomes stable. Upon stabilizing the creature can choose to expend one of its hit dice and immediately regain hit points equal to the maximum roll of their hit die.

subclassFeature.name: Medical Neutrality
entries: Beginning at 7th level you learn to move about the battlefield unscathed. If you use your action to restore hit points, grant temporary hit points, or stabilize a creature, you gain the effects of the Dodge action until the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Field Surgeon
entries: When you reach 13th level your knowledge of medicine allows you to perform great feats of healing, on and off the battle field. As an action on your turn you can use one of the following abilities detailed below:

items: {@b Restorative Boost}. You touch a creature and can end one debilitating effect. You can reduce their exhaustion level by one, or end one of the following conditions: blinded, charmed, deafened, paralyzed, poisoned, a reduction to an ability score, or a reduction to their hit point maximum.
{@b Resuscitate}. Touch a creature that has died within the last minute. They are returned to life with one hit point as if you had cast the revivify spell on the creature.

entries: Once you use one of these abilities you cannot use either again until you complete a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Master Physician
entries: Your knowledge of medicine and the inner workings of the body is peerless. Starting at 17th level, whenever you restore hit points, or grant temporary hit points, the creature gains the maximum amount of hit points, instead of rolling.
Additionally, any creature within 30 feet of you that spends hit dice at the end of a short rest can treat the hit dice as their maximum roll.

subclassFeature.name: Student of Truth
entries: Beginning at 3rd level your dedication to uncovering the truth gives you special insights into creatures and their motivations. When you adopt this Academic Discipline you gain proficiency and Expertise in Insight and Investigation, which means your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make with these skills. If you are already proficient in Insight or Investigation you gain proficiency with another skill of your choice from the savant skill list.

Additionally, your familiarity with those that wish to obfuscate the truth allows you to glean additional information through observation. When you designate a creature as the target of your Adroit Analysis you learn of either a skill in which they are proficient, or if the current appearance of the creature is its true form.

subclassFeature.name: Astute Offense
entries: Your experience searching for truth has honed your ability to sense deceptions. Starting at 3rd level, you have advantage on any ability check you make to see through an illusion or to determine if a creature is lying to you.

In addition, your time spent analyzing everything you see has improved your observational abilities. When you make a weapon attack against a creature that you have designated as the target of your Adroit Analysis you can use Intelligence, in place of Strength or Dexterity, for the damage roll.

subclassFeature.name: Astute Defense
entries: The increased speed at which you are able to make systematic observations about the world around you allows you to better defend yourself. Starting at 7th level, when you are targeted by an attack you can use your reaction to apply your Unyielding Mind bonus to your Armor Class. You must use this reaction before you determine whether the attack hits or misses, and the bonus to your armor class only applies for the duration of the triggering attack.

subclassFeature.name: Peerless Insight
entries: Beginning at 13th level, your senses are almost impossible to deceive, even with powerful magic or other supernatural abilities. As an action, as long as you are not both blinded and deafened, you can focus your senses to detect whether one of the following is within 30 feet of you:

items: - An active illusion spell or illusion effect.
- The presence of an invisible creature.
- A shapechanger not in their true form.
- A secret door or hidden trap.
- Any other magic designed to deceive the senses.

entries: You can sense that something is hidden or that an effect is attempting to trick you, but you gain no insight into who or what is hidden, its location, or into its true nature.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses of it when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Master Seeker
entries: Upon reaching 17th level, your observational skills allow you to exploit the weaknesses of a creature better then most. When you, or a creature that you can see within 60 feet, hits a creature that is designated by your Adroit Analysis with a weapon attack, you can use your reaction to turn the attack into an automatic critical hit.
Once you use this ability you must complete a short or long rest before you can use it again.

entries.name: Seekers of Knowledge
entries: Almost every official class in Dungeons & Dragons 5th edition has a subclass who's themes reinforce the base identity of the class. The Champion fighter, the Oath of Devotion paladin, and the Life Domain cleric are some examples. For the savant, the Seeker serves this role, improving the potency of the base class abilities without adding too much complexity.

subclassFeature.name: Student of War
entries: When you adopt this Academic Discipline at 3rd level you dedicate yourself to the study of war and the skill necessary to lead others on the battlefield. You gain proficiency in the History skill, and your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make. If you are already proficient in History you gain proficiency with another skill of your choice from the Savant skill list.
You have also spent some of your time preparing to directly engage in battle. You gain proficiency with medium armor, shields, and all martial weapons that lack the heavy property.

Your time studying battle tactics allows you to glean additional types of information through observation. When you mark a creature with your Adroit Analysis you learn the creature's armor class and any resistances, immunities, or vulnerabilities they have.

subclassFeature.name: Tactical Commander
entries: When you adopt this Academic Discipline at 3rd level you learn to use your knowledge of battlefield tactics to empower your allies. You learn the following Orders that you can issue as an action on your turn.

items: {@b Attack Order}. Your command bolsters a creature's determination. Choose one creature within 30 feet that can see or hear you. The next time that creature takes the Attack action, before the beginning of your next turn, they can make one additional attack.

{@b Defensive Order}. Your words inspire creature's to protect themselves. As an action, choose one creature within 30 feet that can see or hear you. That creature gains a bonus to their armor class equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1) until the beginning of your next turn.

{@b Rallying Order}. Your insights allow creatures to maneuver around the dangers of the battlefield. Choose one creature within 30 feet that can see or hear you. That creature can use their reaction to move up to their full movement speed without provoking opportunity attacks.

{@b Steadfast Order}. Your words inspire tenacity in your allies. Choose one creature within 30 feet that can see or hear you. That creature gain a bonus to all Strength and Constitution ability checks and saving throws equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1) that they make before the beginning of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Unwavering Resolve
entries: Your position as a leader does not afford you the comfort of succumbing to your base instincts. Beginning at 7th level, you are immune to the Frightened condition.
Additionally, when you use your action to issue an {@i Order} you can make one weapon attack as a bonus action on that turn.

subclassFeature.name: Strategic Genius
entries: Starting at 13th level, your experience as a commander on the field of battle allows you to strategically issue commands to multiple allies. When you use your action to issue an {@i Order}, you can issue one additional {@i Order} as part of the same action. Each {@i Order} must target a separate creature, as an individual creature can only follow one {@i Order} at a time.
Upon reaching 17th level you can issue up to three {@i Order} as part of the same action. Each Order must still target a separate creature.

subclassFeature.name: Master Tactician
entries: Your tactical mind ranks among the greatest military commanders of history, and your presence inspires heroic action in your allies. Starting at 17th level when you target a creature with an {@i Order} they gain temporary hit points equal to double your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1).
